Fields.DialogueText: *ALARM*
@BATTLE
Koooorrrra! Hold it right there, damn you!
Eeep!

Fields.MenuText: I suppose that beats the Roman solution to that kind of dereliction.
Probably less painful than flogging. I suppose that's not allowed these days, either.
Don't make my sailors mutilate themselves, Ashigara.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, yeah, much easier than having your buddies beat you to death.
Appreciate the classics, eh, Kanchou?
Oh, I don't make them do anything. They'll do it themselves when they know they've done wrong by us and their sen'yū.
You just leave this bit up to Ane-san, eh, Kanchou? I've got it covered. I'll make wolves out of these sailors from the eight corners of the earth.
Does this deck look properly swabbed? Does it, punk?
Ah... I. Um. Yes?
Teme! Zakeruna!
Sorry, Ane-san! Err. No, ma'am.
Glad we agree on something. Fix it. Or I'll demand your lazy ass make it up to the crew, me, the Kanchou, and the Emperor. The traditional way.
Know the word "yubitsume," punk?
Yes, ma'am. Aye-aye, ma'am.
I didn't know a sailor could run quite that fast in waters like these.
Ah, Kanchou, they just need the right motivation. Then you'll really see what they can do.
Motivation like cutting off fingertips?
That's not motivation, Kanchou. It's an apology - to the crew, me, you, and to his Divine Majesty - for failing in one's duty to the family.
Nah, that was more to put the fear o' the Emperor into him. You gotta do something a bit more than slack to demand yubitsume. Falling asleep on watch, more like.
Still just, if you ask me. Leaving your sen'yū exposed to the enemy... what greater failure can there be for a bushi?
Kuso! Hold that thought!
Wolves, huh? Interesting choice of animal.
The Brits called me the Hungry Wolf last time I visited.
I learned about wolf pack doctrine when I went to Germany after that. Wolves, too. The strength of the wolf is the pack. The strength of the pack is the wolf.
Kipling? You're surprisingly well read, Ashigara.
Well, thank you, Kanchou. I...
... Hey, what's surprising abo--
Oi! Kanchou, chotto matte.
What is it, Ashigara?
You acted surprised when I paraphrased Kipling the other day. What gives? Do I not look like a scholar to you?
That might just hurt my feelings, you know. Implying I'm some bakayarō or something.

Fields.MenuText: I just haven't seen that side of you before, is all.
I'm not terribly well read myself, so I was impressed.
You act more like a wild wolf than a warrior sometimes. People see the face you show them.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm... acceptable. Keep up, Kanchou - you're in for a whole hell of a lot of sides.
Yare yare. That's no good, Kanchou. I'll lend you some books. You'll never be a top officer and warrior if you don't keep your mind sharp.
You should be more perceptive than that, Kanchou. Sweeping assumptions like that can sweep you right into the jaws of a hungry wolf.
We have a lot to learn about each other, Kanchou. Just keep an open mind. I promise I'll surprise you.
... Well, now. Seems we have a change to get to know each other better right now, Kanchou.
What do you--
*ALARM*
Ah, hell. Battle stations!
What better learning experience than the heat of battle?
My wolves will reveal our enemies for the lame, whimpering dogs they are. Draw steel, you craven bitches!
@BATTLE
They're closing, Ashigara!
Hah! We'll put paid to them fast enough.
@BATTLE
Ah, exercise. I'm just sad we didn't get close enough for a swing or two with my blades.
Helm!
Yes, Ane-san?
Next time we engage, flank speed when I call for it. And weave us in close. I want to gut them with my sword.
How's that sound, Kanchou?
So long as you hit them with your guns first. We don't want to get sunk on the way in.
Well, of course! With my suite of weapons I'll pummel those hags back to the sea floor at any range.

Fields.MenuText: If any range will do, why get up close and personal?
Almost sounds like you're having fun, Ashigara. Don't forget we have work to do.
You're a lot of things, Ashigara. I can say for certain that meek is not one of them.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll be right up front with you, Kanchou. I like brawling.
Haaaai. Don't worry, Kanchou - I know what I'm about. I just fight with a happy heart.
See, Kanchou? We're getting to know each other better already.
Say, Kanchou... That junior officer who just walked by. Do you know him?
The wh... hmm. No. Must be new.
He had an odd look. I'll have to investigate.
Seems she's pretty concerned about the crew. Maybe she's serious about the whole pack thing.
Oi, Kanchou. The heck's all this paperwork?
This is the not-fun part about being a warship captain. Never mind running a small fleet that has to be able to operate worldwide...
... Looks like most of this is budget stuff.
In something like eleven currencies. Probably more. Almost certainly more.
Hmm... Our cash flow's a mess, is what you're telling me.
Funding comes in stops and starts from the parent nations. We make do with what we have.
Simple as anything, Kanchou! We just start charging a small monthly fee to ports and settlements in our area of operation. To ensure their safety, of course.

Fields.MenuText: Not a bad idea, actually. Go straight to the people and let them decide what their safety's worth.

Fields.DialogueText: If they don't like it, they just need to raise hell with their governments to start funding the INPF properly. Either way, the little people get protected.

Fields.MenuText: Isn't that just a protection racket?

Fields.DialogueText: That's such a crude way to phrase it, Kanchou.

Fields.MenuText: No extorting civilians.

Fields.DialogueText: Not like I can extort my own sailors. And the Funayūrei don't seem to value anything besides scrap iron and tacky clothes.
Cheap-ass coin-chasing courtesan.
Avarice excepted.
Well, worry not, Kanchou. I know just the thing to distract you.
What's that?
A Funayūrei flotilla just over the horizon!
@BATTLE
Korrrraa! You there! Tell the turret crews I've got a bottle of sake for each of them for their efforts.
What about 3's crew?
Except No. 3.
Yes, A--
Yes, Ane-san!
They know where they slipped up. Their timing was off by at least forty seconds in that last fight.
What, no yubitsume? No flogging?
They'll have to decide how to make up for their failure.
Kanchou, I told you - I'll never make a sailor, officer, or anyone do anything like that. It's not discipline. It's an apology. They always have a choice.
After all, the strength of the pack is the wolf, and the strength of the wolf is the pack. The weak spots in our armor must be encouraged.
No one worth their blade wants to let down their sen'yū.

Fields.MenuText: How many sailors have actually performed yubitsume?

Fields.DialogueText: More than you'd expect, but I couldn't tell you. Once it's done, it's done. The matter's closed; no reports, no paperwork.
Just go see the ship's doc for a bandage.

Fields.MenuText: And if they're not worth their blade?

Fields.DialogueText: Then we chuck 'em overboard. Preferably at port, but possibly earlier if they're really trash - or worse, a coward.

Fields.MenuText: You know, the more I look at you, the more strange you get.

Fields.DialogueText: A woman's nothing without a little mystery. Besides, I'm not just a woman. I'm a martial spirit sent in your hour of need.
It's important to sweep the gomikuzu out of our ranks before it rots and festers. It can destroy a family from within.
You're not talking about your average family, are you?
Picked up on that, have you? That's why I also call it a wolf pack. Our enemies stay lean, mean, and hungry. So should our pack.
I don't know about you, Kanchou, but I'd much rather live to see peace in this world than die heroically.
I admit I was expecting just about the opposite from you.
Bah! I'm willing to die, but that doesn't mean I want to. Especially when my death means the death of everyone that depends on me.
*ALARM*
Enough chatter, Kanchou. We have work to do!
@BATTLE
Yare yare, Kanchou. Giving in to your animalistic desires already?
... Need you to check the timing on the guns.
Ah, Ashigara. I need you--
Well, I might not mind. Prove yourself a warrior and I might just let you into my den.
Oh, is that all? Shame.
Not to worry, Kanchou. I can feel they're perfectly calibrated from here. The Chief Gunnery Officer deserves a reward.
Hmm. Ashigara, I was thinking... What will you do if we win? When the war ends?
I'm not really built for peace. Your countries know this. I don't think they'd refrain from breaking us up once we're no longer needed.
Still... should we survive to the end, I'll just paint. Work on my poetry. Maybe find someone who can appreciate a refined beauty like me.

Fields.MenuText: Wait, wait. You paint?
You write poetry? Huh. I can actually see that.
Refined is certainly a word.

Fields.DialogueText: In several styles, actually. I've been working on calligraphy, too.
In Japanese and English. Every warrior should write poetry. How else will you compose a beautiful jisei, a death poem?
Your sarcasm might just hurt my feelings, Kanchou.
You just keep your eyes on me, Kanchou. I promise you'll see all sorts of interesting things. I might even make your heart skip a beat.
From fear? Or something else?
A little of both if you're lucky. I--
*ALARM*
Kuso. We have company! And just when the mood was getting interesting...
@BATTLE
Oho! Is that all?
Well, yes, ma'am, but--
No buts. And call me Ane-san.
What does that mean?
Big sister. This ship's a family, see? People can be awkward around guests. Guests can feel awkward in other people's homes. So we need to make you family.
I suppose that makes sense, ma'... Ane-san.
That's the spirit! Now, off with you.
What was that all about?
That was Ensign Holland. We fished him out of the drink a while back after a Yankee ship got blasted. He volunteered to join the complement.
He was the one who was out of sorts the other day?
Hai. We just need to get him settled in. I'll put him to work. Share some sweat and sake and he'll be fine.

Fields.MenuText: You're showing me another interesting side of you, Ashigara.
Hmm... sweat and sake? Is that all?
I never had to do anything like that when I came aboard.

Fields.DialogueText: Keep studying me so intensely and you might make a lady feel nervous.
Not like we need him to make a blood sacrifice or anything.
Well, you're the kanchou. The crew don't need to accept you. They need to respect you. Bonding like Holland needs would be between you and me.
Keep me apprised of Holland's progress. I want to make sure my crew's in top shape. You never know when--
*ALARM*
... That might happen.
Korra! Let's go!
@BATTLE
Come here, you demons! I've got a blade with your pennant numbers on it!
Ashig... oh, I'm sorry. Am I interrupting you?
@BATTLE
No, Kanchou. I felt your footsteps on my deck plates.
You're that in tune with yourself?
When I meditate like I was just doing? Yes. In a zen state - like when I write poetry after battle - I can pick you out by your gait anywhere aboard.
Watching me that closely, are you?
I know all my crew like that. You're all part of me on some level, after all. A ship is nothing without a crew. The strength of the--
--Pack is the wolf. The strength of the wolf is the pack.
You know me pretty well yourself. It's true, though. Divided we are nothing. Together, even the mightiest yōkai should fear us.

Fields.MenuText: You really think Morganas can get scared?
I'm not sure I would want to know exactly what my sailors are doing at all times.
Can I read your poem?

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe. Cowardice certainly does.  If not fear, we'll make them at least respect us.
It's not that precise, thankfully. I just know where everyone is, more or less. If they're healthy.
Not yet, Kanchou. This poem is special, after all. It must be perfect.
I'm glad we're bonding, Kanchou. We win respect from our enemies for our skills, but it is your respect I desire above all.
Do you really worry about that?
Sometimes. Perhaps think about what it means to respect me, and then tell me if you do later on.
Oi, Kanchou. Sign this.
What is it?
Don't you trust me? Just sign it.
Sometimes I worry about trusting you too much.
Kanchou, I'm your loyal wolf. Your word is law, second only to the Emperor himself. I just don't want to waste your time with details.
Details are half my job.
It's a reassignment for Holland. I'm putting him in charge of one of the turrets in our main battery.
He has to roll up his sleeves, get in with the sailors, and lead them if he wants to earn their respect and brotherhood.

Fields.MenuText: It's a sound plan. Good call, Ashigara.
Just throwing him in command of a post? Could get dicey.
Clear these sorts of things before you have me sign any documents, please.

Fields.DialogueText: Praise from the kanchou! Lucky me.
That's true at any rank. If he's a weak link, we need to know immediately. This is what's best for everyone.
Like I said, Kanchou. I need you to trust me.
Now we'll see what Holland is made of.
That's a wicked grin on your face.
That's a mean thing to say to a lady, Kanchou.
You're probably not wrong, though. My sisters say I have a wolfish smile. Especially when I'm hunting.
What are you hunting now?
The same thing I'm always hunting, Kanchou. The worthy.
Worthy challenges, worthy foes, worthy sailors... and a worthy kanchou.
*ALARM*
How do you think you're doing on those fronts?
Pretty well, I'd say.
I really can't tell if she's messing with me sometimes.
@BATTLE
Korrrrra! You there! Seize that sailor!
What's going on here?
I didn't do anything!
Damare! That's the problem, damn you!
You abandoned your post in combat for no reason. You're not even dirty or bloody.
Give me one good reason not to spill your guts across the deck myself!

Fields.MenuText: Ashigara! That's enough.
Have you lost your mind?
A coward? In our crew? Spare your blade the indignity and toss 'em overboard.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I'm just getting started, Kanchou!
I'm getting pretty damn close.
Ryōkai, Kanchou-dono. Fish bait it is.
Someone take this sailor below and toss her in the brig. Round up the crew from her work section and begin investigating.
Wait. Here. Take this tantō.
You have the opportunity to apologize for your failure. I suggest you use it.
Did she just... oh, hell. Should I stop them?
*ALARM*
Damn it. Another group's moving to engage!
@BATTLE
Kanchou! I've come to inform you that the matter with the sailor who deserted her post has been resolved.
How do you mean?
Do you really want to know?
... I notice you have that tantō back.
It was returned properly.

Fields.MenuText: Will the sailor's performance be degraded?
A bit harsh, don't you think?
If you're satisfied that the matter is settled, I am.

Fields.DialogueText: With a sword? A bit. For their actual duties? No. Not once she's healed up.
Leaving your packmates to die is far harsher. Yubitsume is a mercy.
I am, Kanchou. Thank you for trusting me.
I am your sword. Your will made manifest. These sailors give themselves to me to be forged into something greater.
I promised you wolves of steel, Kanchou. If we die, it shall be honorable and glorious.
You're taking this very seriously, Ashigara.
It's a matter of honor, and therefore of life and death.
*ALARM*
Speaking of life and death...
Subarashi. Fight alongside me with your whole heart, Kanchou. Pounding those oni into scrap ought to burn away today's frustrations.
@BATTLE
So that's more or less the crux of it, Captain. What should I do?
Well, I think Ashigara's advice still holds true.
*ALARM*
I think I see where you're going with this. We'll have to pick it up later.
Of course. Same place.
@BATTLE
So Ane-san has been very helpful, but I'm just not making good progress.
I know what Ashigara would tell you. Be bold. You've led in combat. Lead on deck, too.
Maybe get involved with martial arts training? Show your fighting spirit directly.
I fenced at university... and I know some of the crew train regularly with swords. All right. Thank you, Captain!
Right, Holland - dismissed. Carry on.
I was wondering who had made a beeline for your office so quickly after we secured from battle stations.
What was that about? Holland was practically running out of there.

Fields.MenuText: Just reinforcing your previous advice.

Fields.DialogueText: It's a challenging environment. No shame in asking for further help.

Fields.MenuText: Mentoring junior officers is part of my job. Holland needed some tactical advice with your sound strategy.

Fields.DialogueText: If we can't solve his issue together, maybe he needs to seek a new line of work.

Fields.MenuText: Holland's still nervous asking you questions, I think. You are a bit intimidating, after all.

Fields.DialogueText: Intimidating? Me? Kanchou, I'm wounded. I'm the very heart of ladylike grace, composure, and poise. A delicate flower.
Well, I think he's been put on the right track. We'll see what develops.
Damn it, where is... oh. There she is! By the shrine.
Oh, that must be the door to her quarters. Ashigara!
Hah!? Kanchou! Kuso.
Why did you just slam the door to your quarters?
It's, ah... I value my privacy, see? I can't let just anyone into my inner sanctum. Not even to sneak a peek.
It's, uh... bad karma. Or something. Maybe my fortune from New Year's said it was a bad idea? Anyway... that.

Fields.MenuText: Okay... I'll just pretend that any of that made sense.
You can just say you don't want any guests, Ashigara.
Well, now I really want to see in there.

Fields.DialogueText: Perfect. I'm glad I have such a kind and understanding kanchou.
It's not not wanting guests, per se...
No! Er. I. Uhm... suppose it wouldn't be so bad if it's you, Kanchou. Just... not now. Okay?
Oh, look at the time! I'm late for threatening someone! Or maintenance. Something. Bye, Kanchou!
She ran off. What in the world was that about? Guess she really doesn't want people in her den...
*ALARM*
Just a few more seconds and she wouldn't even have needed an excuse.
But it really makes me wonder what's in there, and why the bold Ashigara's so shy about it...
@BATTLE
Hai. There's a specific scent. Yowamushi... Cowardice is near.
The emotion, the act, or the Morgana?
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
You're watching the horizon pretty intently, Ashigara. Your ears are perked up, too.
The oni, Kanchou, though by her nature she is all three.
By that nature I abhor her and her ways. More than normal oni.
Cowardice is the enemy of all warriors.

Fields.MenuText: Do the two of you have some sort of history?
Don't lose sight of the mission. We can't make this personal.
The feeling's mutual. Find her so we can reward her with the coward's lot.

Fields.DialogueText: I know my duty, Kanchou. I will not fail you.
Now you're speaking my language, Kanchou.
She's coming closer. Kanchou! Battle stations! Give the order!
You heard the lady! Battle stations! Sound the alarm!
Oi! Kanchou! Something to strike down!
@BATTLE
See that, Kanchou?
Looks like the usual swordsmanship training.
Aye... but watch this. Look who's joining them.
Ensign Holland? With an American officer's saber...
We'll have to get him a proper sword if he manages his trial and eventually promotes to lieutenant.
Seems he's squared off with the officer leading the group.
Oho! Look at that!
Damn! They just exploded into action.
He grasps the basics, but clearly doesn't have much training. He's got passion, though - Mifune there can't get cocky.
Damn! Some brutal punches from Mifune. I felt those from here.
This is combat swordsmanship, not some pretty sport. Plus, they're barely slowing him down. Mifune punches like a freight train. Those blows had to hurt.

Fields.MenuText: This doesn't seem terribly safe.
Half a month's pay says Holland takes first blood.
I should work on my fencing.

Fields.DialogueText: If you wanted safe, you should have chosen another lifestyle.
You're on. If you lose, you're spending it on sake and drinking it with me.
I'll train with you any time, Kanchou. It'd be my pleasure.
Strike! Mifune's got him!
Look again, Ashigara. I think they got each other. Look at Mifune's cheek.
It seems that they - and we - have a draw.
Suppose I'll buy half the sake, you buy the other half, and we'll drink it together as I demanded. Not a bad outcome at all.
What's Holland doing now? He's bowing... and offering a handshake to Mifune.
I can hear them with these ears of mine. He's asking to join them, and asking Mifune to instruct him in the art of Japanese swordplay.
I'll take the sailors crowding in around them both as a good sign.
Seems he finally got off on the right foot with them.
That busu... she's still skulking around somewhere.
Wait - you mean Cowardice? Where is--
Quite a scowl you're wearing.
Matte, Kanchou. I don't know yet. She likes to slink around like some sort of bakeneko, playing games instead of fighting like a warrior should.
You really despise her, don't you?
Words cannot express my loathing for what she represents. She is a failure. An enemy all must face, and many will fall to.
She must be resisted at all costs, or all is lost. Pride. Honor. Your life and the lives of your loved ones.

Fields.MenuText: How far does that go, though? Would you say a true warrior knows no fear?
I agree. Cowardice... fear... They're demons in our hearts, and they must be conquered.
No greater enemy than the one within us all.

Fields.DialogueText: Only fools feel no fear. Being a warrior is mastering your fear.
Well said, Kanchou.
Hai... the enemy within us all, indeed.
So I despise Cowardice. I turn my guns on her every chance I get.
You want to see the enemy in every sailor's heart? There she stands.
So she stands in mine. I am born of my pack's hearts in turn.
Getting poetic on me, Ashigara.
Perhaps I'll share more with you later. For now... I have located Cowardice.
In that case, let's show her our courage.
Ryōkai! Battle stations!
@BATTLE
Hmm...
Ashigara?
Ashigara, I need you to...
Huh!? Oh! Kanchou! Gomen. I was lost in thought.
Clearly. What's on your mind?
Oh, uh... wolf pack operations. How they can apply to surface ships in our tactical situation.
Deep thinking. But isn't that a submarine tactic?
Sure. It's harder with surface ships, but if you spread out destroyers as scouts with fast-moving heavies, it can still apply.

Fields.MenuText: What if the quarry detects your destroyers?
Isn't that more or less just modern naval warfare? Find the enemy and crush them?
Hmm. Let's wargame this tonight.

Fields.DialogueText: They will. Wolves herd deer into ambushes. We can do the same, or bait them with a destroyer. Trickery is a form of stealth.
Perhaps. I think it's the intent and mindset that really makes the difference.
A night battle, is it? Hai, Kanchou, it would be a pleasure. I'll bring a nice bottle of something to enjoy as we plan their demise.
The only issue I find is that you can't really use anything with serious meat. Maybe a fast fleet carrier or something.
To really make it work, you need destroyers... and cruisers with a mix of speed and endurance. Then you get in and crush the prey the hard way.
Old-school, in some senses.
Just because a plan's old doesn't mean it's not good.
*ALARM*
Speaking of which! Let's demonstrate the value of some old-fashioned violence.
@BATTLE
Ah, Kanchou, good timing! Shh. They're starting.
What's going on, Ashigara? Is that Ensign Holland?
Yes. Holland, newly promoted Able Seaman Nowsde, and a few others are performing sukizake with their immediate superiors.
What's sukizake?
A ritual exchange of sake cups. The junior and senior exchange cups. The senior drinks his or her fill while the junior merely sips.
It's bringing them into the family by oath. Holland in particular distinguished himself recently, as I more or less hoped he would.

Fields.MenuText: I thought that things like that were supposed to be performed with your leader.
Hmm. I never did anything like that.
Is this type of ceremony used for other things? Or just this?

Fields.DialogueText: It is, but the level it's conducted at varies. I taught them to do it like this. You know, more personal.
You don't have to. I owe you my fealty, so they do too. Without question.
Besides, the seniors are pledged to me, so now the juniors are too.
Ahem! I. Ah. Yes, it is. Ask me about it another day, maybe.
Well, I'm glad that's settling itself.
It all comes out in the end, eh, Kanchou? Trust my methods. They work.
I'm starting to see your poi--
*ALARM*
Chikushō! They snuck up on us.
Battle stations!
@BATTLE
Later, Kanchou. I've got a lot on my mind.
@BATTLE
What's the matter, Ashigara? You seem upset.
Walk with me.
What's this about?
Look. The wreckage. That's what this is about.
We sank some Morganas. What's your point?
For now. They'll come crawling back, and more will die for their hate.
Perhaps more literally than ever... cowards die a thousand deaths, but the valiant taste death but once.
Shakespeare. Very worldly once again, Ashigara.
Kanchou, some wise warriors once said that the heart of being samurai - of bushido - is death. Do you know what that means?

Fields.MenuText: It's a pretty bleak philosophy. Obvious, though.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't think it is.

Fields.MenuText: I'm familiar with the philosophy. All warriors are in some form.
Dealing death... always being at the edge ourselves. It's our ally, companion, and foe.

Fields.DialogueText: Humor me anyway, Kanchou?
We live forever on the edge of a katana, forever in twilight. But that's not what I mean.
I believe that a warrior embracing death isn't suicidal. It isn't a death wish. It's an acceptance of the fate we all face.
The heart of bushido - of being samurai - is accepting that death will come when it comes. The time of your end is unknown, and we must face it boldly.
A philosopher too, eh, Ashigara?
I have been reading jisei - death poems - recently. Seeking insights into our enemy who so defies their fate.
Find any?
Only that they are cowards. They fear death. They are attached to the world of suffering... and in their fear they increase that suffering a thousandfold.
Kanchou, one day we too shall face our end. If it is in battle against this foe... I will face my end boldly with you beside me.
It'd be an honor, Ashigara... but I think we'd both rather put these demons down hard and make sure they stay down.
You can count on that too, Kanchou. By my honor.
Oi, Kanchou! Still in your office? You're working too hard. As your ship, I demand you take a break.
A break, is it? What kind of break?
A little drink. Sake. Tea. Both, if you're so inclined. I have everything ready.
All prepared, are you? All right, grab a chair.
Damn, that's good sake.
By the way, Ashigara... sakizuke. You said it was used for other rituals than the one the crew does. Like what?
I, ah... it's part of the Shinto wedding ceremony, most notably. Bride and groom exchange cups three time to symbolize the burdens they'll share.

Fields.MenuText: Not sure how I feel about alcohol being the cornerstone of a wedding.
I see. That's quite beautiful. I imagine it would be interesting to watch, carried out properly.
Heh. Now I'm concerned about how they might see each other if they need a stiff drink to cope.

Fields.DialogueText: It's barely what you'd call a drink. Purely ceremonial. And purified sake has many meanings.
I would imagine so. I've never seen it in person. I doubt I will unless I wed.
Oh? Any candidates?
Kanchou! You can't just ask a woman that!
Exchange sake three times as a symbol of the marriage bond... interesting indeed.
A funny thought, but I'd guess you'd drink before the ceremony if that was your concern.
Oh? Seems that has your mind whirling. Got someone in mind, maybe? Tell me who!
What would you do if I said you?
I'd punch you in the shoulder for teasing me.
Heh, fair enough.
Hmm... we have some more time. Up for a game of shogi?
*ALARM*
Let's earn it.
With pride!
@BATTLE
There they are, Kanchou! Don't let them get away!
@BATTLE
Hmm...
Deep in thought again?
Kanchou, I think we have a problem.
We already sank the problem.
Perhaps... but look. Isn't there a lot of flotsam around? I think the yōkai were hunting merchant shipping. We just surprised them and got the jump on them.

Fields.MenuText: That's a pretty serious problem if it's true.
I need more evidence than that to take to Command.
Sounds like something the enemy would do... Cowardice in particular, if they're attacking unarmed vessels.

Fields.DialogueText: Hai. It must be dealt with expediently.
Drop our speed. I'll get us the evidence. I'm on the trail of something. I can smell it.
You read my mind. It's exactly the kind of plan she'd come up with.
By the way, Ashigara... are you aware that your ears move when you focus on something?
... Naturally. Why wouldn't they move?
Fair. I just realized your ears look like an Alsatian's when you're excited about something.
Comparing a wolf to a mere dog isn't exactly polite, Kanchou.
It's not a bad thing! It's just unexpectedly cute, is all.
C-cute?
I. Uh. We're wasting time! Come on. Let's get to work.
She's surprisingly cute in other ways, too. If there's one thing I know for sure, it's that Ashigara's full of surprises.
I heard a secure message came in from HQ.
Intelligence has reviewed our report and they think you're right. Command wants us to do something about it.
They're working on convoy systems, but with the other wars on, that's delicate in a lot of places.
So we need to intercept Cowardice and her cronies now before they cause too much damage.
Allowing them to put proper safeguards in place, right.
I'm ready. We're ready. This bitch needs a lesson in manners, and we're the right people to give it to her.

Fields.MenuText: Don't get too eager on me now, Ashigara. Duty first.
Let's run wild on them.
Put all that passion into your guns and maybe Cowardice will stay dead this time.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course, Kanchou, sumimasen. I am a wild wolf, but I am a warrior too.
Keep saying things like that and I might just start howling!
We can only hope, Kanchou.
I'm going to give it all I've got. My love, my anger, and all of my sorrow! Honor demands that Cowardice dies her thousandth death.
*ALARM*
Oh, look... a chance to get our blood up. Coming, Kanchou?
Wouldn't miss it.
@BATTLE
You're pacing. It's making the crew nervous. What's wrong?
My heart is burning with a need to kick a torpedo down Cowardice's throat.
I'm restless. Running at full tilt. All keyed up.
You need to take a break or you won't be fighting fit when we do find her.
Perhaps you're right, Kanchou. Tell me, how do you relax?

Fields.MenuText: With a stiff drink or some tea, usually.
Creating always helps me. Painting, poetry, whatever - even if I'm terrible at it.
I always try to find new things to take a stab at.

Fields.DialogueText: Heh, valid enough. Some matcha would be good... and a tea ceremony always focuses me.
I'd like to see your creations sometime. I'll show you mine if you show me yours.
We're similar in that sense. Hmm...
You're right, Kanchou. I should try to relax a bit.
After this battle. Once we find Cowardice. I'd like you to join me for a drink.
We sit together for tea or something all the time, Ashigara. Why so formal?
In my quarters.
Oh. Oooh. Are you sure?
Very. If there's anyone I can invite into my den, it's you.
Into the jaws of the enemy and the den of the wolf, eh? It's going to be interesting, at least...
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
We've got them now.
It was just a matter of time before we forced the coward to go to ground.
She'll be at her most dangerous now, like any cornered animal.
It won't help her. We're wolves, and we'll rip her apart like a lame deer.

Fields.MenuText: Keep your head in the game, Ashigara. Don't let your mind wander. I need the warrior, not the wolf.
Heh, don't actually start trying to eat her. She's almost certainly rotten.
You heard the lady. All hands, battle stations. No surrender. No retreat. Today, we fight!

Fields.DialogueText: Of course, Kanchou. I'm right beside you - now and always.
We have better meat in the galley to feast on after, anyway.
Tennōheika Banzai! To your stations! We won't win the war today, but we can put this coward to rest.
Captain! Cowardice is coming about!
Get those guns laid and loaded! I want that cruiser smashed!
Get the Z flag into the air and start howling, my fine wolves. We have prey to slaughter!
@BATTLE
Ah, Kanchou, good timing. Come in. The sake should be perfectly warm, and I snagged some food from the galley.
Sounds good, but I... damn. Your room's a mess.
Pour, then, and we'll do it.

Fields.MenuText: [Exchange sake cups with Ashigara once, and drink your fill.]
[Exchange sake cups with Ashigara three times, drinking each time.]

Fields.DialogueText: Well, here we are. Finally I get to see just what's inside the hungry wolf's den.
Fresh yakitori, cold beer, and warm sake. This is the good life, eh?
Eh... yeah. I know. That's part of why I don't let people in my inner sanctum. Just the people I trust.
Is that many people?
Just you so far. My sisters, I suppose, if they're ever around. Though even then I'd try to avoid having them in here. I'd just catch a lecture.
Sounds like you and your sisters are pretty different.
Very. They're... kusomajime. Straitlaced. By the book. They don't agree with my methods, but they can't argue with my results. That's why I've always been the flagship when we've sailed together.
Enough about them, though. Tonight's about us. In addition to celebrating, Kanchou, I was wondering... if you might perform sakizuke with me.
I thought you said we didn't need to do that. You offered me your fealty when you chose me, didn't you?
Something like that... but I know you now. I know you well. Respect you. Understand you... and I think you understand me too. So I'd like to formalize my oath to your service.
Bonded as we ought to be, Kanchou. Let's keep each other strong and sharp. Our enemies won't slow down.
Kanchou... do you really... Ah! No, it's nothing. I... I understand.
The atmosphere got kind of heavy there for a second, huh?
You know, you have so many interesting faces. The hungry wolf. The bold warrior. The insightful artisan. The wild thug. I like this softer face of Ashigara, too.
N-now I feel like you aren't taking me seriously or something!
Just the opposite. Now, let's get into that food, shall we?
I'll drink to that!
